texts.text: options

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 🤔  This is another post in a set of posts on  options trading . If you are new to options trading, you may want to start with some of my earlier posts.
texts.text: 🤔  This is another post in a set of posts on  options trading . If you are new to options trading, you may want to start with some of my earlier posts.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You know your terminology, you know your max loss, and you are ready to start. Now you're faced with the difficult question all new options traders face:
texts.text: You know your terminology, you know your max loss, and you are ready to start. Now you're faced with the difficult question all new options traders face:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: How do I choose which option to sell?
texts.text: How do I choose which option to sell?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At first, you learn to look for the trades that are right for you. This post explains some of the things I look for when I make a trade, and how I compare different trades to see which one is right for me.
texts.text: At first, you learn to look for the trades that are right for you. This post explains some of the things I look for when I make a trade, and how I compare different trades to see which one is right for me.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Determine how much you want to risk
texts.text: Determine how much you want to risk

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're starting the wheel strategy, then you are selling a put contract on a stock at a particular strike price. Options contracts involve 100 shares of the underlying stock, so you can multiply the strike price by 100 to know how much money you are risking on the trade.
texts.text: If you're starting the wheel strategy, then you are selling a put contract on a stock at a particular strike price. Options contracts involve 100 shares of the underlying stock, so you can multiply the strike price by 100 to know how much money you are risking on the trade.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For example, if you sell a $90 put option on AMD, then you are risking $9,000 on the trade. The chances of AMD rocketing to $0 is extremely unlikely, but anything is possible.
texts.text: For example, if you sell a $90 put option on AMD, then you are risking $9,000 on the trade. The chances of AMD rocketing to $0 is extremely unlikely, but anything is possible.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Compare the size of your trade to the size of your account. Risking $9,000 in a $10,000 account may not be the best idea for new traders since you are putting 90% of your capital at risk. The goal is to avoid "blowing up" -- when you lose so much that you don't have enough capital left for good trades. 💣
texts.text: Compare the size of your trade to the size of your account. Risking $9,000 in a $10,000 account may not be the best idea for new traders since you are putting 90% of your capital at risk. The goal is to avoid "blowing up" -- when you lose so much that you don't have enough capital left for good trades. 💣

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If my conviction on a trade is very strong (I know the company, I know the stock's personality, and I've done my homework), then risking 15-20% of my account on the trade seems reasonable. For companies I know less about, I won't go past about 5-10% of my account on the trade.
texts.text: If my conviction on a trade is very strong (I know the company, I know the stock's personality, and I've done my homework), then risking 15-20% of my account on the trade seems reasonable. For companies I know less about, I won't go past about 5-10% of my account on the trade.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Watch your stock's calendar
texts.text: Watch your stock's calendar

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There a certain events in the lifetime of a stock that can cause wild swings in price. Selling options around the time of these events creates increased risk because you really don't know what happens during the event. Some of these events include:
texts.text: There a certain events in the lifetime of a stock that can cause wild swings in price. Selling options around the time of these events creates increased risk because you really don't know what happens during the event. Some of these events include:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Dividends.'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Dividends.'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Splits.'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Splits.'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Product events and announcements.'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Product events and announcements.'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Earnings.'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Earnings.'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've written about earnings in previous  options trading  post, but it bears repeating: earnings are unpredictable. Even if the earnings report is stellar, you may see the price fall off drastically. Why? Perhaps investors want to take profit. Perhaps investors were expecting more on earnings and the expectations were already "priced in".
texts.text: I've written about earnings in previous  options trading  post, but it bears repeating: earnings are unpredictable. Even if the earnings report is stellar, you may see the price fall off drastically. Why? Perhaps investors want to take profit. Perhaps investors were expecting more on earnings and the expectations were already "priced in".

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Don't sell options around earnings unless you know what you're doing. Even if you think you know what you're doing, you probably don't. 😉
texts.text: Don't sell options around earnings unless you know what you're doing. Even if you think you know what you're doing, you probably don't. 😉

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Choosing a strike price
texts.text: Choosing a strike price

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once you know the stocks that fit your trading style, it's now time to choose your strike price. IThere's a critical options calculation to know here: delta.
texts.text: Once you know the stocks that fit your trading style, it's now time to choose your strike price. IThere's a critical options calculation to know here: delta.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Delta runs from 0 to 1 and some software represents it as a percentage. It describes how much the option price moves as the underlying price moves. Here are some examples:
texts.text: Delta runs from 0 to 1 and some software represents it as a percentage. It describes how much the option price moves as the underlying price moves. Here are some examples:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='1.00 delta (or 100%):'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='1.00 delta (or 100%):'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='0.50 delta (or 50%):'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='0.50 delta (or 50%):'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='0.25 delta (or 25%):'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='0.25 delta (or 25%):'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of my puts are sold near the 0.25 delta mark. This means that there is roughly a 75% chance that my put will finish out of the money (I keep the premium and there is no loss). There is a 25% chance that my put finishes in the money and I will be assigned stock (possibly at a loss).
texts.text: Most of my puts are sold near the 0.25 delta mark. This means that there is roughly a 75% chance that my put will finish out of the money (I keep the premium and there is no loss). There is a 25% chance that my put finishes in the money and I will be assigned stock (possibly at a loss).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We could spend all afternoon talking about delta and theta, but a good start is to sell your puts somewhere near 0.25 delta. I will sometimes move towards 0.30-0.35 delta if I feel very bullish about a stock or I will move towards 0.20 delta if my conviction is less strong.
texts.text: We could spend all afternoon talking about delta and theta, but a good start is to sell your puts somewhere near 0.25 delta. I will sometimes move towards 0.30-0.35 delta if I feel very bullish about a stock or I will move towards 0.20 delta if my conviction is less strong.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Calculate your return
texts.text: Calculate your return

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We wouldn't sell options if we didn't expect a return! It's a good idea to know your potential return for any trade you make. Let's take an example trade and calculate our maximum loss and potential return.
texts.text: We wouldn't sell options if we didn't expect a return! It's a good idea to know your potential return for any trade you make. Let's take an example trade and calculate our maximum loss and potential return.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD is trading at $92.79.
texts.text: AMD is trading at $92.79.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You choose to sell a put at the $85 strike (.26 delta) that gives $2.42
texts.text: You choose to sell a put at the $85 strike (.26 delta) that gives $2.42

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Maximum loss is
texts.text: Maximum loss is

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your breakeven point is $82.58. As long as AMD stays above that price, you
texts.text: Your breakeven point is $82.58. As long as AMD stays above that price, you

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can calculate your return with:
texts.text: You can calculate your return with:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: bid / (strike - bid) * 100
texts.text: bid / (strike - bid) * 100

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . For our trade, that's:
texts.text: . For our trade, that's:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . If AMD stays over $85 through the life of the contract, you get a 2.9% return.
texts.text: . If AMD stays over $85 through the life of the contract, you get a 2.9% return.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's another angle we can use to analyze the trade: an annualized return. Annualized returns consider how long you had to tie up your capital on a trade while you wait for your return. Would you rather make a 2.9% return in one week or one year? I'd much rather make it in a week.
texts.text: There's another angle we can use to analyze the trade: an annualized return. Annualized returns consider how long you had to tie up your capital on a trade while you wait for your return. Would you rather make a 2.9% return in one week or one year? I'd much rather make it in a week.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The annualized return calculation extends the calculation we've already done above:
texts.text: The annualized return calculation extends the calculation we've already done above:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: (potential return / days held) * 365
texts.text: (potential return / days held) * 365

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . We know we have a 2.9% potential return and 28 days to expiration, so we can calculate the annualized return:
texts.text: . We know we have a 2.9% potential return and 28 days to expiration, so we can calculate the annualized return:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you did this trade successfully over and over again all year long, you could possibly get a 37.8% return at the end of the year on these trades. Don't take this as a given, though. I usually use this to compare different trades against each other to see which one is a better use of my money.
texts.text: If you did this trade successfully over and over again all year long, you could possibly get a 37.8% return at the end of the year on these trades. Don't take this as a given, though. I usually use this to compare different trades against each other to see which one is a better use of my money.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Comparing trades
texts.text: Comparing trades

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's say you like the AMD trade from the previous section, but you're also looking at another stock that you really like. How do you choose which one to sell? I usually consider the annualized return. If I can make more money with the same amount of capital, I'll go for that trade.
texts.text: Let's say you like the AMD trade from the previous section, but you're also looking at another stock that you really like. How do you choose which one to sell? I usually consider the annualized return. If I can make more money with the same amount of capital, I'll go for that trade.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: FUBO is another stock I follow and I have strong conviction on it as well. Here's a trade there:
texts.text: FUBO is another stock I follow and I have strong conviction on it as well. Here's a trade there:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: FUBO is trading at $37.72.
texts.text: FUBO is trading at $37.72.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You choose to sell three puts at the $30 strike (.22 delta) that gives $2.13
texts.text: You choose to sell three puts at the $30 strike (.22 delta) that gives $2.13

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Maximum loss is
texts.text: Maximum loss is

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your breakeven point is $27.87. As long as FUBO stays above that price, you
texts.text: Your breakeven point is $27.87. As long as FUBO stays above that price, you

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Return:
texts.text: Return:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Annualized return:
texts.text: Annualized return:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The FUBO put has a much higher annualized return, which gets my attention. However, FUBO is riskier for me since the stock has a much shorter history and it is much more volatile. Sure, I can make more money with this trade, but the risk is substantially higher.
texts.text: The FUBO put has a much higher annualized return, which gets my attention. However, FUBO is riskier for me since the stock has a much shorter history and it is much more volatile. Sure, I can make more money with this trade, but the risk is substantially higher.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After checking the calendars, I found that AMD has earnings in the next week! That breaks my trading rules since I avoid earnings under almost all conditions!
texts.text: After checking the calendars, I found that AMD has earnings in the next week! That breaks my trading rules since I avoid earnings under almost all conditions!

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Making the trade
texts.text: Making the trade

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Every stock and options trade has a bid/ask spread. Buyers say "I will pay $1.00 for this trade" and that's the bid. Sellers say "I will only sell if someone pays me $2.00" and that's the ask.
texts.text: Every stock and options trade has a bid/ask spread. Buyers say "I will pay $1.00 for this trade" and that's the bid. Sellers say "I will only sell if someone pays me $2.00" and that's the ask.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Under most situations, I sell at the midpoint of the bid/ask spread. This means that on a spread of 1.00-1.10, I will sell at 1.05. The trade executes within 30 seconds unless the stock price is moving quickly.
texts.text: Under most situations, I sell at the midpoint of the bid/ask spread. This means that on a spread of 1.00-1.10, I will sell at 1.05. The trade executes within 30 seconds unless the stock price is moving quickly.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the stock is moving fast or if you really want to be sure your trade gets in, sell at the bid price. That almost always guarantees that a buyer is waiting to buy your contract as soon as you write it.
texts.text: If the stock is moving fast or if you really want to be sure your trade gets in, sell at the bid price. That almost always guarantees that a buyer is waiting to buy your contract as soon as you write it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can sell at the ask or even higher if you really want to, but your execution could be delayed or it may never execute.
texts.text: You can sell at the ask or even higher if you really want to, but your execution could be delayed or it may never execute.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Congratulations! You sold your first option. What do you do now?  (Keep reading.)
texts.text: Congratulations! You sold your first option. What do you do now?  (Keep reading.)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: After the trade
texts.text: After the trade

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Your trade may turn red immediately after it executes: don't panic! Most brokers show the midpoint price (or "mark") and if you sold at the bid price, your trade will be red at first. Also, if the stock price dipped a little, your trade will be red for a short while. Take a deep breath.
texts.text: Your trade may turn red immediately after it executes: don't panic! Most brokers show the midpoint price (or "mark") and if you sold at the bid price, your trade will be red at first. Also, if the stock price dipped a little, your trade will be red for a short while. Take a deep breath.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One of the first things I do (after  logging my trades on thetagang.com ), is to put in a buy order at a 50% gain. Consider our AMD trade earlier ($85 put with $2.42 premium). I would enter a buy order for $1.21 with "good til canceled" (GTC). There's no more work to do! As soon as I can get a 50% gain, the trade executes and I keep my $121 profit!
texts.text: One of the first things I do (after  logging my trades on thetagang.com ), is to put in a buy order at a 50% gain. Consider our AMD trade earlier ($85 put with $2.42 premium). I would enter a buy order for $1.21 with "good til canceled" (GTC). There's no more work to do! As soon as I can get a 50% gain, the trade executes and I keep my $121 profit!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Why stop at 50%? I have several reasons:
texts.text: Why stop at 50%? I have several reasons:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: It reduces my chance of loss because my money is at risk for less time.
texts.text: It reduces my chance of loss because my money is at risk for less time.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Emotion is removed from the trade. My trade is closed the moment 50% gains
texts.text: Emotion is removed from the trade. My trade is closed the moment 50% gains

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: I have work and kids. I don't have time to hover over my broker interface
texts.text: I have work and kids. I don't have time to hover over my broker interface

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: It almost always leads to a better annualized return.
texts.text: It almost always leads to a better annualized return.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A better return with a smaller profit? How can that be? 🤔
texts.text: A better return with a smaller profit? How can that be? 🤔

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's  take an example from a PLTR trade I did last month . I sold two $25 puts for $2.04 premium each that had a 128% annualized return. However, the 50% trigger closed the trade in two days when PLTR rocketed upward unexpectedly.
texts.text: Let's  take an example from a PLTR trade I did last month . I sold two $25 puts for $2.04 premium each that had a 128% annualized return. However, the 50% trigger closed the trade in two days when PLTR rocketed upward unexpectedly.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If I held the trade from January 20 to February 12 and PLTR finished above $25, I would have made $408 (128% annualized return). Instead, I made $204 in two days (Jan 20-22). What's our annualized return here?
texts.text: If I held the trade from January 20 to February 12 and PLTR finished above $25, I would have made $408 (128% annualized return). Instead, I made $204 in two days (Jan 20-22). What's our annualized return here?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Potential return:
texts.text: Potential return:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Annualized return:
texts.text: Annualized return:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Wow! 🤯
texts.text: Wow! 🤯

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That's 1,624% versus our original 128% annualized return and my money was only at risk for two days. What if PLTR suddenly drops next week? I avoid that risk by collecting profit early and freeing up capital for another trade.
texts.text: That's 1,624% versus our original 128% annualized return and my money was only at risk for two days. What if PLTR suddenly drops next week? I avoid that risk by collecting profit early and freeing up capital for another trade.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: One big part of risk management in the market is to keep your capital at risk for the shortest amount of time possible to make the returns you want.
texts.text: One big part of risk management in the market is to keep your capital at risk for the shortest amount of time possible to make the returns you want.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Good luck! 🍀
texts.text: Good luck! 🍀

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
texts.text: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
